newsitem.title: USA: Capsized barge still snarling Mississippi traffic.
newsitem.headline: Capsized barge still snarling Mississippi traffic.

text.p: Federal and state officials struggled on Monday morning with plans to remove volatile cargo from a capsized barge in the flood-swollen Mississippi River, while marine traffic backed up near the accident site, the Coast Guard said.

Plans to unload the benzene and gasoline mix were scrapped on Saturday after officials with the Atchafalaya Basin Levee District won a temporary injunction in state court to prevent the barge owners from drilling holes in the hull.

Levee District officials maintained that any risk of explosion, which could knock out a section of the mainline levee protecting the west bank of river, was unacceptable. A full hearing on the injunction was to be held later Monday.
Other efforts to use existing but submerged valves were delayed on Sunday after a plume of the benzene mix leaked from a valve being replaced, Coast Guard spokesman Chris Haley told Reuters.

The next attempt to lighter the barge, owned by Ingram Barge Co. of Nashville, was expected about 10:30 a.m. EST, Haley said. Once lightering begins, it will take at least 24 hours to complete. Then cranes can be used to right the barge.
By daylight Monday, 27 tows, involving numerous barges, were backed up waiting to move downriver, Haley said. Nineteen barges moved upriver during the night.
Marine traffic in the area was restricted to one way, one vessel or tow at a time past the capsized barge. Southbound traffic was allowed only during daylight hours.
The Coast Guard reported just one minor incident of runaway barges on the river over the weekend near Convent, La., and said the barges were quickly corraled.

A mobile home spotted floating downriver toward Baton Rouge was pushed onto the bank by a tug to keep it away from vessel traffic, a spokesman said. "We have no idea where it came from, but no one was inside."
In the past week several incidents blamed on the high water's swift current, have closed the river in sections from Baton Rouge to the mouth of the river at Southwest Pass.
River traffic at Baton Rouge has been hampered since a string of 25 barges under tow hit a bridge on March 17. Two rock barges sank, one is missing and the third capsized.
